awd_titl_txt: EAGER:   Engaging Stakeholders with Prototypes: Practitioner  Approaches during Front-end Design
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) grant supports fundamental research into the use of prototypes during the earliest stages of engineering design projects. This is a critical juncture in most projects. Engineering designers formulate a design problem based on their understanding of user needs and wants. Misunderstandings at this stage can imperil the success of a project. Prototypes can be key to understanding what people need and want in a product, and thus determining the ultimate success of the design. However, current reports of prototype usage suggest that they are not leveraged to their full potential when designers are interacting with potential users of the design. The goals of this research are to capture best practice strategies used by industry practitioners based on their descriptions of engineering design projects as well as observations of them in action as they use prototypes to engage with users. The study will focus primarily on medical device design problems due to their richness as an engineering design problem and their importance to society. Fundamental strategies identified in this study will be transferrable, impacting the ways practitioners in many engineering areas approach stakeholder engagement. This will promote greater productivity and innovation in engineering product design and, ultimately, better products for end users. 

This research investigates design practitioner behaviors and strategies for using prototypes during the front-end phases of design, especially for engaging stakeholders for the purposes of defining design problems and eliciting product requirements. Research methods include a combination of design project-centered semi-structured interviews (both retrospective and near real time), document review, and observations. Data analysis draws takes an iterative approach, allowing patterns and themes to emerge. A combination of inductive and deductive analyses will ensure the results are robust and appropriately contextualized. Outcomes of this research include a framework for using prototypes to engage with stakeholders during early design phases and a series of case studies documenting how prototypes have been successfully leveraged.

por.por_cntn:
The front end of design is critical for product success. It includes activities such as problem identification, problem definition, requirements and specifications development, and concept generation and development. Prototypes can play important roles across all of these activities in front-end design work, but historical emphases on prototype use in design have been to support back-end design activities. Our research aimed to characterize the use of prototypes beyond back-end activities of verification and validation of design constraints, as we focused on prototypes as tools to support engagement with diverse stakeholders – those who may impact or be impacted by a particular design – during the early stages of a design process.

The research findings from our work included rich descriptions of the types of prototypes designers create to engage with stakeholders, the kinds of stakeholders with whom they engage, and a collection of prototyping strategies industry practitioners use to support meaningful engagements with stakeholders during front-end design work. Differences across industries (medical device, automotive, consumer products, and product design more broadly) and engagement settings (including in-person and remote) were also investigated.

In addition to the scholarly conference proceedings and publications generated from this work, the findings were translated into educational materials and tools to support use among novice and practicing designers, case stories that described real examples of prototypes usage for stakeholder engagement during the initial stages of design, and a front-end prototyping tool that directs designers to leverage the prototyping strategies for stakeholder engagement based on their design goals and stakeholder access. Both the case series paper and front-end prototyping tool were shared with participants at the Harvey Mudd Design Workshop and are currently in use at multiple academic institutions to support capstone design coursework. 

The prototyping strategies for stakeholder engagement in front-end design work that we identified through this research can support both notice and experienced designers in successful engagements with stakeholders throughout their work as well as help them improve their design approaches by using the tools for planning and reflection. Ultimately, the work aims to support designers across multiple disciplines in considering, connecting with, and applying information from stakeholders in their design work, making their outcomes more successful and applicable to the intended people and contexts in which they are meant to benefit.
